docs.lead_paragraph: It was a week to give owners of blue chips the blues. The greatest names of American capitalism seemed to vie with one another to see which company could have the most depressing news. General Electric joined the parade yesterday, revealing that its auditors had discovered that, for the last three years, it had failed to apply correctly an accounting rule and would have to restate its financial results.

headline.main: Not the Week To Be or to Own The Bluest Chips

docs.snippet: It was a week in which the greatest names of American capitalism seemed to vie with one another to see which company could have the most depressing news.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ask Senator John Kerry if he will run again for president in 2008, and the answer comes back swift and sure: ''I don't have any clue.'' But from a clean, well-lighted carpenters' union hall in St. Paul, where Mr. Kerry talked to 250 enthusiastic supporters about children's health care on Tuesday, a very different picture emerged. Nurses, union members and former campaign volunteers threw Mr. Kerry softball questions, while a half-dozen College Republicans, including identical twins dressed up as ''flip-flop'' sandals, staged a protest in the parking lot. Inside the hall, parents who said they were unable to afford insurance shared tearful stories.

headline.main: On the Go, but Not Running, Kerry Looks Like a . . . Shhh!

docs.snippet: Senator John Kerry must still prove himself to fellow Democrats, keeping his presidential prospects alive even as he insists it is too soon to talk about 2008.

docs.lead_paragraph: S.&P. Downgrades Debt Of Ford and General Motors General Motors and the Ford Motor Company lost their investment grade ratings, pushing the two major automakers into the ranks of junk bonds, and rattling the financial markets. The downgrade by Standard & Poor's, the credit agency, reflects rising pessimism about the kinds of cars that G.M. and Ford have placed at the center of their company strategies, as well as worries that the two automakers may not emerge any time soon from their troubles. [Page A1.] Investigation of A.I.G. Share Price Federal prosecutors have opened an investigation into whether Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the insurance giant American International Group, orchestrated an effort to manipulate the company's stock price in his final weeks as chief, people officially briefed on the inquiry said. [A1.] A Plea for an Aviation Policy The struggling airlines are begging Washington for policies that will help them survive. The latest person to seek assistance is the chief of Delta Air Lines, Gerald Grinstein. He called on federal officials to establish a comprehensive aviation policy that would offer companies guidelines in areas like bankruptcy, mergers, fuel prices and taxation. [C3.] Cardinal Health to Shut Unit Cardinal Health is shuttering a unit that trades in the secondary drug marketplace, in which drugs are purchased and resold before finding their way to consumers. [C12.] 'American Idol' Starts Inquiry The producers of ''American Idol'' and the Fox network, which broadcasts the program, said that they had begun their own inquiry into claims by a former contestant that he received coaching and financial assistance from one of the show's judges, Paula Abdul. [C5.] Cablevision Lost $118.9 Million Cablevision Systems said that it had a loss of $118.9 million in the first quarter of the year, but revenues rose 6 percent as premium cable services like Internet access grew. [C4.] Gas Prices Hurt Discount Stores J.C. Penney and Nordstrom led sales gains at retailers, while discounters like Wal-Mart Stores trailed, hurt by gasoline prices. [C3.] Reporter for USA Today Resigns A reporter for USA Today resigned after his editors said he violated the paper's standards by lifting quotations from other newspapers without attribution. [C5]. MCI Reports a Small Loss MCI, the long-distance carrier, posted a small loss in the first quarter as it made deep cost cuts to offset steep declines in revenue. The company, based in Ashburn, Va., lost $2 million, or 1 cent, in the first quarter after losing $388 million, or $1.19 a share in the quarter last year. Revenue plunged 12 percent from the quarter last year, to $4.8 billion. [C4.] Productivity Rose in First Quarter Business productivity growth accelerated unexpectedly in the first quarter, but in a signal of building price pressures, labor costs also picked up, a government report showed. [C12.] An Alert for Advertisers Madison Avenue was warned that it risked being marginalized by changes in technology. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C5.]
docs.snippet: S.&P. Downgrades Debt Of Ford and General Motors  General Motors and the Ford Motor Company lost their investment grade ratings, pushing the two major automakers into the ranks of junk bonds, and rattling the financial markets.     The downgrade by...

docs.lead_paragraph: There was a brief flurry of outrage when Congress passed the 2003 Medicare bill. The news media reported on the scandalous vote in the House of Representatives: Republican leaders violated parliamentary procedure, twisted arms and perhaps engaged in bribery to persuade skeptical lawmakers to change their votes in a session literally held in the dead of night. Later, the media reported on another scandal: it turned out that the administration had deceived Congress about the bill's likely cost.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column says 2003 Medicare bill is object lesson in how special interests hold America's health care system hostage; says law subsidizes private health plans, which have repeatedly failed to deliver promised cost savings, and creates unnecessary layer of middlemen by requiring that drug benefit be administered by private insurers; says it specifically prohibits Medicare from using its purchasing power to negotiate lower drug prices; notes that Rep Billy Tauzin, who shepherded drug bill through Congress, now heads all-powerful drug-industry lobbying group, and Thomas Scully, former Medicare administrator, negotiated for future health industry lobbying job at same time he was pushing drug bill; calls Medicare bill corrupt deal created by corrupt system (M)
docs.snippet: The 2003 Medicare bill is an object lesson in how special interests hold America's health care system hostage.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In making a case for a one-size-fits-all health care system, Paul Krugman (''A Private Obsession,'' column, April 29) ignores the private sector's progress in adding value to our health care system and stretching consumers' health care dollars.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    In making a case for a one-size-fits-all health care system, Paul Krugman (''A Private Obsession,'' column, April 29) ignores the private sector's progress in adding value to our health care system and stretching consumers' health...

docs.lead_paragraph: The relentless rise in health care costs is causing states and businesses to fight over whose job it is to insure workers. And nearly two dozen states, struggling with the growing burden of providing public assistance to people with jobs but no insurance, are looking to shift more of the financial burden onto the workers' employers. Last month, for example, Maryland, which spends roughly $350 million a year on health care for the uninsured, passed a bill requiring the state's very largest employers to spend at least 8 percent of their payrolls on health benefits for their workers. Lawmakers elsewhere, including Connecticut, are considering legislation that may also require some companies to provide coverage, either directly or by paying into a state fund.

headline.main: States and Employers Duel Over Health Care

docs.abstract: Relentless rise in health care costs is causing states and businesses to fight over whose job it is to insure workers; nearly two dozen states, struggling with growing burden of providing public assistance to people with jobs but no insurance, are looking to shift more of financial burden onto employers; Maryland, which spends about $350 million a year on health care for uninsured, approved bill last month requiring state's largest employers to spend at least 8 percent of their payrolls on health benefits for their workers; lawmakers elsewhere, including Connecticut, are considering legislation that may also require some companies to provide coverage, either directly or by paying into state fund; some measures would let companies bid on state contracts only if they provided health insurance for their workers; some states would embarrass companies whose workers are on Medicaid or other forms of state assistance by publishing employers' names--as Massachusetts did with list of companies including Dunkin' Donuts, Stop & Shop and Wal-Mart Stores; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Nearly two dozen states are looking to shift more of the financial burden of health care costs onto workers' employers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Kirk Kerkorian's announcement of a tender offer for 28 million shares of General Motors' stock caught the attention yesterday of retirement finance specialists. General Motors has promised tens of billions of dollars in pensions and retiree medical benefits to its work force -- promises that are hurting its ability to compete. And while Mr. Kerkorian said yesterday that his investment would be passive, his track record left many analysts skeptical.
docs.abstract: Kirk Kerkorian's announcement of tender offer for 28 million shares of General Motors' stock catches attention of retirement finance specialists; GM has promised billions of dollars in pension and retiree medical benefits to its work force--promises that are hurting its ability to compete; many analysts are curious as to what designs Kerkorian might have on company's retirement plans; occasionally, investor finds way to separate ailing company's pension plan from its business operations and send obligations to federal government (M)
docs.snippet: Kirk Kerkorian's announcement of a tender offer for 28 million shares of General Motors' stock caught the attention yesterday of retirement finance specialists.

docs.lead_paragraph: WellPoint, a health insurance provider, said it had agreed to acquire closely held Lumenos for $185 million to add about 214,000 participants in plans like health savings accounts. The Lumenos accounts will increase the options WellPoint offers to employers seeking to shift more responsibility for health care costs to their workers, said Mark Boxer, WellPoint's chief strategy officer. WellPoint, which is based in Indianapolis, has about 100,000 members enrolled in health savings accounts and health reimbursement accounts, said John Watts, head of the company's national accounts.

headline.main: WELLPOINT TO BUY LUMENOS, A HEALTH SAVINGS COMPANY

docs.abstract: WellPoint acquires Lumenos for $185 million to add about 214,000 participants in plans like health savings accounts (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I suggest that Laura Bush wake her husband up around 9:30 p.m. and travel around and look at the folks in this country working the second and third shifts on their second and third jobs in an attempt to make ends meet.

headline.main: Laura Bush, Comic: They're Not All Laughing

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    I suggest that Laura Bush wake her husband up around 9:30 p.m. and travel around and look at the folks in this country working the second and third shifts on their second and third jobs in an attempt to make ends meet.

docs.lead_paragraph: With most of Wal-Mart's workers earning less than $19,000 a year, a number of community groups and lawmakers have recently teamed up with labor unions in mounting an intensive campaign aimed at prodding Wal-Mart into paying its 1.3 million employees higher wages. A new group of Wal-Mart critics ran a full-page advertisement on April 20 contending that the company's low pay had forced tens of thousands of its workers to resort to food stamps and Medicaid, costing taxpayers billions of dollars. On April 26, as part of a campaign called ''Love Mom, Not Wal-Mart,'' five members of Congress joined women's advocates and labor leaders to assail the company for not paying its female employees more.

headline.main: Choosing Sides Over $9.68 an Hour; Parrying Its Critics, Wal-Mart Says Its Wages Must Stay Competitive

docs.abstract: Number of community groups and lawmakers team up with labor unions in mounting intensive campaign aimed at prodding Wal-Mart into paying its 1.3 million employees higher wages; most of Wal-Mart's workers earn less than $19,000 a year; new group of Wal-Mart critics ran full-page advertisement on April 20 contending company's low pay has forced tens of thousands of its workers to resort to food stamps and Medicaid, costing taxpayers billions of dollars; five members of Congress on April 26 joined women's advocates and labor leaders to assail company for not paying its female employees more; labor groups and their allies are focusing on Wal-Mart because they say campaign will not just benefit its workers but also reduce existing pressure on unionized competitors to reduce their own wages and benefits; Wal-Mart's chief executive H Lee Scott Jr defends his company, arguing that wages are primarily determined by market forces and that Wal-Mart pays more than most retailers and provides better opportunities for advancement; graph; photos (M)
docs.snippet: With most of Wal-Mart's workers earning less than $19,000 a year, several groups have teamed up to prod Wal-Mart into paying its employees higher wages.
